newsitem.title: GREECE: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- JAN 16.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - GREEK GENERAL NEWS- JAN 16.

text.p: Leading stories in the Greek general press:

--Evidence of a crisis in ruling party PASOK is growing daily. At yesterday's meeting of PASOK MPs, Prime Minister Costas Simitis stressed that the party was not governing in an effort to ensure privilege or power, indicating modernisers and traditionalists were on course for collision.
--Bullish sentiment in international markets is bolstering the upward trend in Greek shares. The Athens bourse appears to be making a strong recovery from last year's Delta scandal.
--Problems in the sale of state-run enterprises have appeared once again, despite the government's determination to push ahead with its privatisation programme.

--US State Department official Carey Canavaugh is cultivating a climate of "diplomatic optimism", saying that he hopes to have achieved a resolution of the Cyprus problem before Russian S-300 missiles are deployed on the island. Ankara, however, appears to disagree.
--The recent resignation of Deputy Foreign Minister Christos Rozakis was a "symbolic blow" to modernisers in the ruling party, Alternate Foreign Minister George Papandreou says.

--Unionists in the banking sector are demanding a stake in banks' profits - up by 212.7 percent in recent years compared to 3.46 percent in pay increases - as well as a 35-hour working week which, they say, will create 2,000 new jobs.
--Farmers square shoulders for a second round, beginning February 4 with the blockade of road and rail links in Thessaly. On January 28 they will occupy public buildings and services.

--The farmers' decision yesterday to return to the roads was unanimous. Protests will continue, they warn, if the government does not give answers to the demands forwarded last month during the 25-day blockade.
--Real estate prices near the site of Athens' new international airport at Spata have gone sky-high.
--Farmers in the Corinth and Fthiotida areas - the hardest-hit by Sunday's flash floods - will receive loans and a freeze on debts by the Agricultural Bank of Greece.

--The trial of Antonis Daglis - the "Dragon of Votanikos" - was postponed till today after Daglis fainted in court. Daglis is charged with three counts of murder and eight counts of attempted murder and has confessed to raping a number of women before strangling them and cutting up their bodies. --Maria Petrakis, Athens Newsroom +301 3311812-4
